Award.AwardTitle: The Study of Nuclear Physics with Intermediate Energy Probes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although ninety-eight percent of the mass of ordinary matter is due to the strong nuclear force, the present theory of that force (Quantum Chromodynamics) is still not fully understood. This award supports the study of the strong nuclear force by probing the substructure of matter. Almost the entire mass of an atom is concentrated in its tiny nucleus, which is made of nucleons that are either positively charged (protons) or electrically neutral (neutrons). These subatomic particles, however, are not elementary but are themselves composite objects made of quarks held together by glue particles (gluons). The structure of nucleons is a manifestation of the strong nuclear force, which is the strongest force known. This research will help advance discovery and understanding in nuclear physics, and promote teaching, training, and learning. The preparation of junior scientists plays a central role in the supported activities.

The nuclear physics research program at the University of South Carolina (USC) is mainly based at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility in Newport News, Virginia. There, the group uses high-energy electron and photon beams along with sophisticated particle detectors that were developed, in part, at USC as powerful microscopes to study the subatomic world. The group is also preparing the MUSE experiment at the Paul Scherrer Institute in Switzerland. This experiment will address the proton-radius puzzle by scattering muons and electrons off the proton. Through detector development, simulations, management of complex experiments, and data analyses, they will shed light on some of the most profound questions like: What is the structure of the nucleon? What are and how can we excite its internal degrees of freedom? Once excited, in which way does the nucleon decay back to its original state? Does the structure of the nucleon change if it is embedded in dense nuclear matter? The experimental study of these properties gives insight into the nature of the strong force and allows for rigorous tests of the underlying theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of the atomic nucleus and its constituents at the quark level is at the core of the research of the experimental nuclear physics group at the University of South Carolina (USC). Our studies focus on Quantum ChromoDynamics (QCD), humanity?s most advanced hypothesis of how the force between quark and gluons works. The results from our research help address fundamental questions such as: how is the visible mass in the universe generated, why do quarks and gluons not exist as free particles, what is the nature of neutron stars, and what are the properties of dense nuclear matter? Answering these questions is a complex task requiring dedicated experimental observations and careful testing of theoretical predictions against these observations. We have been leading experiments at one of the flagship facilities for nuclear physics research in the U.S., the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (JLab), and at the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) in Switzerland. We have also been engaged in collaborative research at the electron accelerator MAMI in Germany. We are responsible for the construction of critical equipment for major nuclear-physics experiments at JLab and PSI.
A major outcome of this project is the measurement of large sets of observables for various nuclear reactions at JLab. These novel high-precision results are used in theoretical fits to shed light on the excitation spectrum of nucleons and drive the development of new theoretical calculations to unveil details about the force acting between the quarks as they create excited states. In fact, one set of our published data was instrumental in establishing evidence for a poorly known nucleon excited state. Other sets of our published data were essential to shed light on important aspects of how visible mass is generated in the quark-gluon interaction. While it is generally known that the force between a strange and a light quark is different from the force between two light quarks, we lack precise details on this broken symmetry in both cases. Our most recent results will be able to discriminate between different hypotheses about the symmetries of these forces.
In addition to these scientific results, we developed critical equipment for two forefront nuclear-physics experiments. We have designed, built, and implemented the forward time-of-flight detector for CLAS12 experiments at JLab and achieved world-record time-of-flight resolutions for large scintillation counters. We have been instrumental in the development of the Muon Scattering Experiment (MUSE) at PSI, for which we also prototyped and successfully commissioned scintillation detectors.  We have developed software to simulate experiments and to model, readout, and calibrate detectors.
Beyond advancing discoveries and understanding in nuclear physics, a major goal of the PIs is to promote teaching, training, and learning. This project created new theoretical, technical, and computational opportunities for the education of undergraduate, graduate, and postgraduate scientific personnel. Our program gave junior personnel exposure to science at the local, national, and international levels and guided them to acquire the technical, communication, and scientific skills necessary to become successful members of the scientific community. In this project, we have trained two postgraduate, 14 graduate, and ten undergraduate students. Our trainees pursue successful careers in nuclear science, academia, and the industry.
We have been active in professional service to the nuclear community and in promoting nuclear physics. Members of our group have organized several international workshops, including a major research conference at USC, dedicated hadronic-physics sessions at conferences, and have served on numerous International Advisory Committees. We have given lectures at international summer schools and have been active in promoting interest in science and technology among K-12 students. We acted as judges and mentors at regional science fairs and the annual USC Midway Physics Day. These efforts increase the community's awareness and enjoyment of science.
